LeftText: 6	Basil is easy to grow ,
7	and transforms ordinary meals into culinary treasures !
8	Fresh basil not only tastes better
9	than dried ,
10	it actually tastes different ,
11	almost as if it were not the same herb .
12	This article outlines
13	how to plant and harvest basil .
6	Basil is easy to grow ,
7	and transforms ordinary meals into culinary treasures !
8	Fresh basil not only tastes better
9	than dried ,
10	it actually tastes different ,
11	almost as if it were not the same herb .
6	Basil is easy to grow ,
7	and transforms ordinary meals into culinary treasures !
RightText: 8	Fresh basil not only tastes better
9	than dried ,
10	it actually tastes different ,
11	almost as if it were not the same herb .
12	This article outlines
13	how to plant and harvest basil .
14	Method 1 of 3 :
15	Starting Seeds
16	1 Choose the kind of basil
17	you wish to grow .
18	Basil comes in many different varieties ,
19	each of which have a unique flavor and smell .
20	Read up on different types of basil
21	and pick out one
22	- or several -
23	that appeal to you ,
24	then order the seeds
25	or buy them at a garden store .
26	Here are a few ideas :
27	Cinnamon basil really does smell like the sweet spice ,
28	and it also has unusually beautiful and fragrant flowers .
29	Lemon basil actually contains citral , an aromatic compound found in citrus fruit ,
30	and smells very lemony .
31	Purple basil is often grown for decoration , as well as its scent and flowers .
32	There are perennial basils
33	which come back year after year ,
34	like African Blue Basil
35	( which has pretty blue veins on its leaves )
36	and Thai Basil ,
37	while most other varieties are annuals ,
38	which you 'll have to plant year after year .
39	Globe and Greek basil are much more difficult to grow ,
40	but form pretty little bushes
41	which stay well - contained .
42	2 Start seed indoors four to six weeks before last frost .
43	Basil needs warm air and sun
44	to do well ,
45	so it 's often easiest to start the seeds indoors
46	instead of risking that they 'll get damaged by frost .
47	If you live in a hot climate ,
48	you can start the seeds outside instead .
49	To figure out when the last frost will be ,
50	consult an almanac
51	or talk with other gardeners in your area .
52	3 Prepare seed containers .
53	Fill flats or individual seed containers with a mixture of equal parts perlite , vermiculite , and peat .
54	Press the mixture slightly
55	to eliminate air pockets .
56	Dampen the mixture with water
57	so it 's ready to provide the right environment for the basil seeds to germinate .
58	4 Plant the seeds .
59	Drop one to two seeds into each container .
60	Cover them lightly with soil .
61	Cover containers with clear plastic kitchen wrap ,
62	so they stay moist .
63	Leave the containers in a sunny window .
64	Twice daily , remove the plastic wrap
65	and sprinkle the containers with more water .
66	5 Remove the plastic wrap
67	when the sprouts emerge .
68	When you see the first green tendrils push up through the soil ,
69	it 's time
70	to remove the plastic wrap .
71	Keep watering the sprouts twice daily ,
72	never letting the soil dry out .
73	When the plants become a few inches tall
74	and their leaves mature ,
75	it 's time
76	to transplant them to a larger container .
77	Method 2 of 3 :
78	Caring for Basil
79	1 Transplant the basil plants .
80	Once two sets of leaves have formed ,
81	basil can be planted into the garden or permanent containers .
82	Basil does not tolerate frost
83	so do n't plant too early .
84	It 's best to put basil somewhere
85	where it will get a good deal of sunshine
86	and have well - drained soil .
87	To plant the basil in the garden ,
88	dig holes
89	spaced at least 6 inches apart .
90	Place the roots in the holes
91	and place soil around the stems .
92	Pat down soil around the plants
93	to eliminate air pockets .
94	If you want to plant the basil in a container ,
95	make sure it 's large enough to accommodate the number of plants
96	you 're growing ;
97	they need to be planted 6 inches apart ,
98	since they grow quite large .
99	2 Keep the soil damp ,
100	but not soaked .
101	Basil does best in well - drained soil ,
102	and should not be subjected to standing water .
103	Water the mature basil plants once a day , in the morning ,
104	so the water has time
105	to soak in
106	and evaporate
107	rather than sitting on the plants overnight .
108	3 Pinch off flower heads .
109	When you see flower buds ,
110	pinch them and two pairs of leaves under them off .
111	Flowers blooming create a hormone change
112	which dramatically reduces the flavor of the leaves ,
113	as well as reducing the amount of foliage
114	which grows .
115	This is called " bolting "
116	and is more likely to happen
117	when there 's extra sunshine .
118	You 'll notice
119	that
120	if you leave the flowers ,
121	the plant will become lanky
122	and the leaves wo n't be as full or tasty .
123	4 Watch for pests and mold .
124	Basil plants are attractive to Japanese beetles
125	the best way to control these pests is to pick them off the plants by hand .
126	If your plants show signs of mold growth ,
127	they may not be getting adequate sunlight ,
128	or they may be too close together .
129	Weed out the smaller plants
130	to give the larger ones more space .
131	Method 3 of 3 :
132	Harvesting and Using Basil
133	1 Harvest
134	and prune .
135	As the plant matures ,
136	pinch off the top two pairs of leaves
137	once a stalk reaches a reasonable height .
138	If you look closely ,
139	at the base of every leaf are two tiny little leaves
140	that will grow outwards
141	if the stem growing between them is cut off .
142	Cut close to those tiny leaves ,
143	but be sure not to damage them .
144	Pinching encourages the plant 's energy to be directed into its stronger stems and leaves .
145	This helps the plants grow bushy .
146	Do n't pinch on the lower part of the stem ,
147	or the basil plants will grow tall and reedy .
148	You want them to get bushy ,
149	so pinch from the top .
150	2 Enjoy the basil fresh .
151	Rinse off the leaves
152	and use the basil
153	to make pesto or a Caprese salad with tomatoes and fresh mozzarella cheese .
154	3 Store the basil in the refrigerator .
155	You 'll probably have more basil
156	than you could possibly eat fresh ,
157	so plan on storing some in the fridge .
158	Wash the leaves ,
159	dry them well ,
160	and wrap them in paper towels .
161	Place them in a food storage container with an airtight lid .
162	4 Freeze the basil .
163	Freezing the leaves whole does n't work very well ,
164	but
165	if you puree it first
166	you can freeze it for months .
167	Place the basil in a blender with a little water .
168	Puree it
169	until smooth ,
170	then put it in a food storage bag
171	and freeze
172	until you need it .

165	if you puree it first
166	you can freeze it for months .
167	Place the basil in a blender with a little water .
168	Puree it
169	until smooth ,
170	then put it in a food storage bag
171	and freeze
172	until you need it .

LeftText: 77	Method 2 of 3 :
78	Caring for Basil
79	1 Transplant the basil plants .
80	Once two sets of leaves have formed ,
81	basil can be planted into the garden or permanent containers .
82	Basil does not tolerate frost
83	so do n't plant too early .
84	It 's best to put basil somewhere
85	where it will get a good deal of sunshine
86	and have well - drained soil .
87	To plant the basil in the garden ,
88	dig holes
89	spaced at least 6 inches apart .
90	Place the roots in the holes
91	and place soil around the stems .
92	Pat down soil around the plants
93	to eliminate air pockets .
94	If you want to plant the basil in a container ,
95	make sure it 's large enough to accommodate the number of plants
96	you 're growing ;
97	they need to be planted 6 inches apart ,
98	since they grow quite large .
99	2 Keep the soil damp ,
100	but not soaked .
101	Basil does best in well - drained soil ,
102	and should not be subjected to standing water .
103	Water the mature basil plants once a day , in the morning ,
104	so the water has time
105	to soak in
106	and evaporate
107	rather than sitting on the plants overnight .
108	3 Pinch off flower heads .
109	When you see flower buds ,
110	pinch them and two pairs of leaves under them off .
111	Flowers blooming create a hormone change
112	which dramatically reduces the flavor of the leaves ,
113	as well as reducing the amount of foliage
114	which grows .
115	This is called " bolting "
116	and is more likely to happen
117	when there 's extra sunshine .
118	You 'll notice
119	that
120	if you leave the flowers ,
121	the plant will become lanky
122	and the leaves wo n't be as full or tasty .
123	4 Watch for pests and mold .
124	Basil plants are attractive to Japanese beetles
125	the best way to control these pests is to pick them off the plants by hand .
126	If your plants show signs of mold growth ,
127	they may not be getting adequate sunlight ,
128	or they may be too close together .
129	Weed out the smaller plants
130	to give the larger ones more space .

131	Method 3 of 3 :
132	Harvesting and Using Basil
133	1 Harvest
134	and prune .
135	As the plant matures ,
136	pinch off the top two pairs of leaves
137	once a stalk reaches a reasonable height .
138	If you look closely ,
139	at the base of every leaf are two tiny little leaves
140	that will grow outwards
141	if the stem growing between them is cut off .
142	Cut close to those tiny leaves ,
143	but be sure not to damage them .
144	Pinching encourages the plant 's energy to be directed into its stronger stems and leaves .
145	This helps the plants grow bushy .
146	Do n't pinch on the lower part of the stem ,
147	or the basil plants will grow tall and reedy .
148	You want them to get bushy ,
149	so pinch from the top .
150	2 Enjoy the basil fresh .
151	Rinse off the leaves
152	and use the basil
153	to make pesto or a Caprese salad with tomatoes and fresh mozzarella cheese .
154	3 Store the basil in the refrigerator .
155	You 'll probably have more basil
156	than you could possibly eat fresh ,
157	so plan on storing some in the fridge .
158	Wash the leaves ,
159	dry them well ,
160	and wrap them in paper towels .
161	Place them in a food storage container with an airtight lid .
162	4 Freeze the basil .
163	Freezing the leaves whole does n't work very well ,
164	but
165	if you puree it first
166	you can freeze it for months .
167	Place the basil in a blender with a little water .
168	Puree it
169	until smooth ,
170	then put it in a food storage bag
171	and freeze
172	until you need it .
